response.answer_text: Here are 10 ways to radically improve your life by becoming more aware 1. Practice mindfulness Mindfulness is a huge topic in-and-of-itself, but I feel obliged to briefly discuss it here. It is one of the philosophies that has recently taken the world by storm. Everyone has a version of what it is and how it can help. To me, it is all about maintaining constant awareness of your body, mind, and feelings. Mindfulness is meant to create congruence between how you feel and think, and how you act. A lot of people actually lack a simple back and forth in this regard. For example, they will have their meal, and completely miss the point when their body was signaling to them that they’d had enough. Consequently, they’d overeat and regret it later. It comes out of a lack of awareness of one’s body. Or, they will be working, bent over a desk, only to feel pain in their neck and shoulders, at the end of the day. Only then, will they realize that they’d been sitting hunched over, and feeling discomfort throughout the entire time. Most of the things I am about to cover can help you improve your mindfulness, but perhaps the best way to do so directly is through meditation. Try to devote several sessions out of your day to do this. The way I do it, is by closing my eyes and trying to completely clear my mind of all thoughts. I only focus on my breath and as soon as something creeps in, I try to let it go. It’s surprisingly difficult, yet refreshing. 2. Always try to see something new in something old This one I also like to call my secret to happiness. If you actually pay attention you will see that no two moments are ever the same, even if you are doing the same thing for the five-thousandth time. There is always something completely unique about the present. What’s great about this is that it also satisfies one of the six human desires, according to motivational guru and personal development coach, Tony Robbins - the need for variety. He correctly points out that the human mind requires not only a certain sense of stability to function, but also variety, excitement, and new experiences. The great thing about seeing something new in something old is that you don’t need to seek out variety, because you can always see it around you. You can never look at a thing in the same way twice, and that helps you appreciate every moment that much more. I was first introduced to this idea, when a mentor of mine gave me the advice to completely cover my ears the next time I am in the shower. This forced me to experience this thing that I was doing every day in a completely new light. I could suddenly hear very clearly, the water dancing off of me and hitting the floor in an entirely new way for the first time; that sensation stuck with me even after I had removed my hands. I had turned something ordinary, into something magical. There are tons of ways to create a habit out of this, but starting small is always a great option. Perhaps the shower trick will help you see the value in it as well. 3. Place yourself in other people’s position This concept gained a lot of prominence due to Harper Lee’s iconic novel “To Kill a Mockingbird”, but it has been around since the Native Americans. As she put it, “You never really know a man until you understand things from his point of view, until you climb into his skin and walk around in it”. Or, as they put it, “Don’t judge a man until you have walked a mile in his shoes”. Whichever way it is you prefer the sentiment, there is little doubt that applying this concept will allow for some much needed perspective in tough situations. To remind yourself often of this, is togrow and expand your capacity for empathy - arguably one of the most important skills in today’s world. Studies have shown that it is the key component of emotional intelligence. What is emotional intelligence? “[It] is defined as the ability to perceive and express emotion accurately and adaptively, the ability to understand emotion and emotional knowledge, the ability to use feelings to facilitate thought, and the ability to regulate emotions in oneself and in others” (Salovey & Pizarro, 2002). So ask this question often, and consider what it can help you uncover about your peers. 4. Ask why 3 times I’ve written about this at great length before here, but it is important enough to shortly discuss it again. With anything you do in life you first have to start with ’why’. Chances are you’ve heard someone say that before you do anything, you should decide what you’re trying to get out of it. That’s true, because when you do something with a clear focus and intent, that is a clear sign of your awareness. The opposite is also true - when we see people around us acting like sheep or zombies - not truly thinking and not really living - it is almost always because they fail to think about ’why’ they are doing the things they are doing. I know, because I used to be exactly like that. This idea of asking why changed everything. We all do it when we are young, but we are often told to stop asking questions, or our questions are dismissed way out of hand - “you don’t know enough about this world yet, if you are asking this”, we are told. At my last job, they were doing things in the most inefficient way possible. It took a newcomer like me, willing to question why, to shake things up. Asking why is the best way to ensure you don’t get set into ineffective patterns. Start to apply this and you will see how much of an impact a simple thing can make and how surprisingly few people do it. 5. Think about how things work This is undoubtedly one of the best ways to increase one’s capacity to actually think. Regurgitating the facts is one thing, and is about as far away from thinking as it goes. True thinking is about connecting the dots. To do that you have to first know what makes up the dots. If you spend some time to consider how things come together and what makes them work you will become much better at noticing the underlying patterns that make up this world. You can see what direction things seem to be headed and plan accordingly. You can grasp a new idea much quicker and be able to consider its significance. That’s what true innovation is all about. Finding an application for a new idea in such a way that seems obvious after the fact, but that others hadn’t even thought of before. I’ve noticed my capacity to connect different seemingly unrelated things improve greatly, by simply thinking about how things work. I like to spend some time each day to just relax, not do anything and let my brain wander around. I find this sort of deep thinking invaluable. 6. Look at the implications So, first you ask why, then you ask how, and finally you say, “so what”. This goes off of what I was saying about how things work. If you know the how, and you know the why, it is much simpler to connect the dots. These components are what makes up the whole innovation process. It is also what makes up the learning process. Think about it. When you learn a concept successfully, it tends to start with you realizing that it is important to learn in the first place. This is the why. Then you know it is important, so you decide to learnhow it works. Finally, for true learning you have to be able to place it within a context. How does it all fit with everything else you already know? It is nearly impossible to forget something learnt in this comprehensive manner. That is how you build up yourmind map - the framework you use to guide you throughout your life. 7. Become super curious I’ve just outlined a way to think for yourself, by using why, how, and so what. Now, I want to say a few words about the thing that helps kickstart the whole process - becoming really curious. Quick quiz, you are most likely reading this on a computer - without looking or pressing the button, what does F5 do? I’d venture to bet that most of you had no idea - that’s okay, neither did I, when I was first asked this question. It made me realize that there is this amazing technology, that most of us use every day, perhaps much more than is healthy or useful, yet I didn’t even know what the buttons do. The least I could do was learn how this thing works, why it behaves the way it does, and get more familiar with what it can do. It is a shame, and it is not because the F5 button will save my life, or because it is crucial knowledge. It is because, I’d never even thought to consider it. I’d never even cared to wonder. The shame is in the pattern of thought I was building up. The world has a lot of wonders to offer, and there are tons of things to learn. BUT, learning doesn’t happen without curiosity. If I never take a second to become curious, how can I hope to expand and fulfill my potential. How can I improve and better myself, and my life? 8. Turn hardships into opportunities “It ain’t about how many times you can get hit, it’s about how many times you can get hit, and keep getting up”. Every single thing that happens to us can be viewed negatively, or positively. Remember, life is not so much what happens to us, but how we respond. How you choose to perceive an experience, often determines that response. I had a friend in high-school, who could use both of his hands equally well for everything. I was quite surprised, and impressed, because I can’t even draw a proper stick figure using my left hand. When I questioned him how he is so good with both of his hands, he responded that it was because he had broken a hand when he was young, so he forced himself to learn using the other one. It’s quite the attitude. Consider that 95% of us, would’ve most probably just taken it as an opportunity to relax and evade work. Being able to adapt like that and use a disadvantage as simply a chance to improve, is an invaluable skill that can stick with you. It’s inarguably a much better way to live. Hence, when something unpleasant happens pay attention to the way you respond, and try to control it. If you can’t do that from the very beginning, at least pay attention to why not, and to how it made you feel. It might be hard in the beginning, but after a time, it will become automatic. 9. Slow down All of these topics are important enough for their own post, and this one specifically already has one devoted to it. The point is, that doing something slowly, requires you to use your full attention on that thing. The key is that you can only do your work slowly if you do it deliberately and that means to focus on the process and on the current moment. By slow, I don’t mean to do everything in such a way as to bore yourself. I mean at a speed that will allow you to pay absolute attention to what you are doing at any moment. The paradox is that even though it will seem that you are doing the task slower, since all of your energy is being channeled into what you are doing, it gets accomplished much quicker and with less effort. Working slowly goes against everything we’ve been taught. You will see as soon as you try it that your whole mind is revolting, screaming at you to start doing things faster. However, by maintaining your concentration you can silence your brain and produce truly outstanding work. You will know you are there when your mind is no longer panicking that the results are not coming fast enough, because you are so engrossed with the process. Anything you do in a rushed state is much easier when you slow it way down. There is no more rush, no more stress, only success. 10. Reflect Any list like this, that attempts to do something so important, would be incomplete without a fair warning - all of this is useless, if you forget to reflect on your experiences. You can’t read this once and remember, learn, and implement everything, all the time. The greatest teacher is yourself. You have no ulterior motive - you will only do this step, if you truly want to improve - nobody can force you to do it, and nobody is going to blame you if you don’t, except perhaps, you. Incorporate the idea of experimenting into your life. There is a reason that scientific breakthroughs happen after extensive testing - it’s good to have a goal, but if you are not experimenting with ways to achieve it, testing, and writing down your results, you can’t hope to nail down what will get you there. For example, I had the idea last year that I needed to get much more out of my day, so I researched for ways to achieve that. I found something related to polyphasic sleeping (sleeping several short times a day, instead of one big time at night). It seemed like a tall task, but I knew that I would never forgive myself if I didn't try. So for the next two weeks I followed the schedule to the dot - I slept for two 40 minute periods during the day, and one hour and 30 minute period at night. By the end of the first week I was feeling terrible, I was walking around like a zombie, and I was extremely close to the point of simply falling asleep at random points during the day, even while walking. So, I terminated the experiment after a while and I instead looked for ways to get more out of my day, through using the time I had better, instead of trying to create more time. The important point is that I had an idea, I went for it, I tested it, and I saw for myself whether it would work for me or not. Nobody is going to do all the hard work to see what works for each and every one of us - we need to do it for ourselves. My advice is to set up daily, weekly and monthly goals, for each of the things that matter to you. Set up clear criteria for what success would mean and what failure would mean. Then, record what worked out well and what didn’t. Adjust and repeat, adjust and repeat.  I hope this list can be at least one-tenth as useful to you, as it has been to me. How To Make Your Life Better By Becoming More Self-Aware  Can self-awareness really help us reach our goals? Most people do not want want to be labeled as narcissistic, as someone absorbed with themselves 24/7. Yet the focus on self, or self-knowledge, is the single most important trait we can develop in life. Self-awareness allows us to understand our needs, fears, desires, habits—everything that makes us tick. Like it or not, the more you know about yourself, the better and faster you can adapt to the changes that happen in business and life. Change is inevitable, and the better you can handle it, the quicker you’ll land on your feet and move on. There’s a big IF, however. Self-awareness is not self-absorption. Self-awareness assumes that you’ll collect information and insights about yourself so you can make improvements. Self-awareness isn’t a magic bullet, but it’s the place to start. It isn’t the empty promise of a self-help book, either. It means you will need to take a close look at the good, the bad, and the ugly, and honestly assess what you find. Socrates was famous for his quote: “know thyself,” but it takes more than intellectual self-reflection to unravel the can of worms that forms your personality. Self-awareness expects you to pinpoint your emotions and spend time with all of them, not just the warm and fuzzy ones. There’s one thing you do not need in life—an inappropriate emotion that pops up without warning and sabotages your promotion or ruins a relationship. For myself, I learned early in my career that I’d better get a handle on how to manage my emotions if I wanted to live long enough to collect my retirement. As part of an arrest team in the uglier part of Oakland, my job was to cover the back door while the FBI SWAT team crashed through the front door with a battering ram. These were the sort of criminals who did not hold day jobs—we had waited until 5:00 am to make certain they had made it back home from the night before. I heard, “FBI, come out with your hands up.” Fear was the emotion that caused my hand to shake as I watched to see if one of the suspects would run out the back door. Even after months of firearms training, I reacted like a mewling newbie. Crap, at this rate I wouldn’t hit the side of the building as my hand shook so bad. I wore a bullet-proof vest and knew I was surrounded by highly skilled FBI snipers, but that wasn’t enough to calm my fear that something could go wrong. Then a scuffle, shouts, and the back door opened. One of my colleagues stepped out and gave me the OK sign that the suspects were in custody. As I lowered my weapon, my fear immediately calmed down—the pressure was off. There’s a good reason to focus on emotions if we want to become self-aware. Our brains are hardwired to make us emotional creatures—first and foremost. No matter how tough and self-controlled we think we are, our first reaction will ALWAYS be emotional. We can dampen or deny our emotions, but we are kidding ourselves if we think we can actually control the way in which our brain processes emotions. You do have total control, however, over the thoughts that follow an emotion. If you are in control, you also have a great deal of power over the way in which you react to your emotions and the situation that created it. Mental toughness is managing your emotions by controlling your subsequent thoughts and behavior in ways that will set you up for success. Are you mentally tough? Take this FREE assessment. The key is to be aware of your emotions. If you are not fully aware of what you are feeling, you’ll be clueless about how to handle it effectively. You cannot change what you do not acknowledge. 1. Look At Yourself Objectively No wants to admit they’re a wimp in the face of trouble. On the day of the arrest in Oakland I had to acknowledge that I needed to do a couple of things. First, face my fear. Second, find a way to overcome it. Self-awareness is not some touchy-feely exercise that is meant to make you feel better about yourself. You’ll need to face who you really are, without the pretense of illusion or vanity. It takes a strong mind to not let your emotions jab you in the stomach when you admit to yourself that you are not Superman or Wonder Woman. If you are not in control of your emotions, you can feel like a loser and give up. How To Make It Work For You: Remember that no one is perfect. The idea is to be honest with yourself and identify those areas that need improvement. Study your reactions to situations that bring up different emotions. Look at this as a critique of your performance, not a criticism. I critiqued my performance at the arrest, acknowledged it sucked and knew right then and there I needed to find a way to turn shit into sugar. 2. Keep A Record Of It If we keep in mind that self-awareness is really about self-improvement, writing in a journal makes it easier to record our reactions. A journal allows us to revisit past situations and reactions so we can gauge our progress in the future. Another advantage of a journal is that it’s full of facts, not memories that get distorted over time. A journal is also an excellent place to record responses that serve us well. It’s not all bad news! If there’s a record on how you kept your emotions under control or expressed them in a way that made a difference, it’s a good way to be reminded that you can keep a lid on it when you need to. How To Make It Work For You: Journals are a private place where you can record your honest feelings. This makes it easier for you to push yourself as you figure out what you want. What would be a better response? How can you respond rather than let loose a knee-jerk reaction. Knowing that I had flirted with a coward’s heart at the Oakland arrest, I rehearsed all possible scenarios and outcomes in my mind before the next one. If the suspect ran, I mentally rehearsed my response. If the suspect shot back, I mentally rehearsed my response for that as well. Bottom line: by continually placing myself (mentally) in a situation where I would feel fear, I was able to control my fear when confronted with the real thing. 3. Pinpoint The Triggers Self-awareness enables us to identify what triggers 1) positive and healthy emotions, and 2) negative and unproductive ones. Once you understand what triggers them, you can begin to notice, and then control them. How To Make It Work For You: Here are things to think about: Stop treating your emotions and feelings as either good or bad.Admit each emotion has something to teach you, even negative ones.Recognize that pretending a negative emotion doesn’t exist doesn’t mean it’s not still there, lurking beneath the surface and ready to sabotage you when you least expect it.Put yourself under surveillance. Notice what event, person or situation provokes a good emotion. Notice what event, person or situation provokes a negative emotion.Keep a journal of what you’ve noticed.Explore why you experienced a good and positive emotion.Explore why you experienced a negative and painful emotion. Did I mention: Remember to journal what you’ve noticed and explored—no matter how unpleasant the emotional experience.Work your way through positive and negative emotions.Express what you are feeling in less than 3 words if it’s a negative emotion. Be honest and stop pretending you aren’t feeling jealous, envious, angry, etc. Do NOT engage in dialogue about these negative feelings, however, as it will only increase your anxiety.Drill down and ask yourself why you do the things you do.Revisit your values.Spot your emotional reactions in others, including movies and books.Use stress as a time to get to know yourself better.Ask for feedback from people you trust.One more time: are you keeping track of this? © 2020 LaRae Quy. Really an important question! If we can be aware, don’t call it ‘self-aware’; because if you are aware, you will automatically be aware of yourself as well. If you become just ‘self-aware’ and not aware of the people and things around you, it would not help you really. Awareness must be holistic, 360 degrees. To be aware, to live in the present, to cultivate witness attitude, are all one and same thing. The first thing you need to realise is: What is it that’s keeping you from being aware? The answer is - continuous train of thinking that one is used to. Our mind is conditioned to travel in the pre-existing grooves. So we just look through life, seeing it with existing lens of familiarity, and we avoid being aware. As soon as an object, or person, or piece of wisdom, comes in front of us, we see it from the lens of what we already know. ‘Oh, I know this! Oh, I know that! He is like this. He is like that.’ This is dangerous. This means we are closed. We can’t be aware. To be aware, we have to forget what we already know and see again. The tree that we pass daily seems the same but it isn’t, it’s changing. If you are attentive, you will notice. The person you know very well and see daily, seems the same, you know him, but he or she isn’t the same… if we are attentive, we can sense. But, for you to be attentive, you need to go slow. A person in a hurry cannot be aware. To be aware requires spending more time with the same things, and using all our senses and the mind more purposefully. We cannot just pass things, we have to see them, feel them, experience them carefully. But we can’t become slow suddenly. To become slow, we should practice stop-and-go method with everything. For everything, just stop and perceive. Between things again, stop. Don’t make life continuous. Stop in between to get your bearings. Every five or ten minutes. Unless you stop, how can you be fresh and spontaneous? Good, you started being slow, and you started stopping regularly to just relax and with that calmness sharpen your perception in order to be more aware. Now, life will again come back to you and ask you to hurry. The mind will try to convince you that the world is moving forward and you are left behind. It will try to tell you not to stop, not to relax. These signals are fraudulent. Pay no attention to these. Nothing is being missed by going slow, in fact if you run fast, everything is missed. No moment will return for you to be live again. So honour it with your slow grace and full attention, and no hurry. Salute the moment by not hurrying. Salute existence by paying close attention. Record everything, feel everything and don't worry about what’s the use of recording and feeling? There’s use. Living itself has no use because anyway we will die one day along with all the purpose, all the use. But if you lived through all moments, you would have used life to experience it. That is very, very, very fulfilling. Now, go back to the beginning and read again. No hurry. Carefully, see what you can take from this message and become aware.

One thing I've recently started and find extremely useful is starting up a regular journalling habit.  I first tried this with a physical journal but eventually ran into several problems  I found staring at a blank page on a journal, waiting to be filled up too intimidating. I either ran out of things to write or just had too much to write that journalling took too long. Journalling became a hassle and too tiring to keep up.   Because of this, the sleek Moleskine journal I bought with amazing plans to chronicle my everyday's life's journey became unused.  Along the way on the Internet, I discovered this amazing free app called Grid Diary (Page on griddiaryapp.com) which solved my problem of being too intimidated by a blank page.  The app has helped me maintain a daily journalling habit and take stock of my day for these 3  simple reasons. 1. It uses prompts to start your writingCan't think at the end of the day? Grid Diary uses a "fill up the form" type of approach which you can customise and fill in as you like.  This has saved me valuable mental energy of thinking of what to write at the end of the day.  Journaling has helped me become more self-aware by forcing me to actively think of how I've spent my day.  Some of the questions I set for myself to answer include: - What are 2 things I am grateful for today? - 1 thing that can be improved- What have I learnt today?- Did I come across anything memorable today?  2. It is easy to access and establish a journalling habit Sometimes at the end of a long work day, you just want to lie in bed and do nothing. I set up a daily reminder near my usual bedtime to write in my Grid Diary, ensuring that I keep writing in my journal no matter how tired I am by the end of the day.   3. I can use other forms of media to document my day Don't feel like writing today? Take photos, screenshots, shoot a video / vlog, voice record  and attach it to your journal entry. I love using photos and screenshots in my journal entries, especially if I come across memorable quotations or quotes on social media which I want to save for future reference.    Like all habits, journalling takes time to reap any benefits for yourself. What I've noticed in myself after establishing this journalling habit are:  - My memory of the day's events has improved. By forcing myself to remember the day's events, I avoid the "sleepwalking through life" type of feeling. - Regular journalling gets your thoughts and feelings out on paper (or on the screen). Only you get to see these words. They can be as eloquent and articulate as you want, or as incoherent and vulgar as you want. What truly matters is that you get the words out on the page.  -  By remembering the day's events, you bring to mind what went well in a (potentially crappy) day. Sometimes all we need are little reminders during a shitty day that "hey, it isn't that bad after all". You'll get through and tomorrow will be a better day.  Want to be more self-aware and reflective? Start a journalling habit today. Use whatever medium and media you are comfortable with, but what is more important is establishing a regular habit for self-contemplation and reflection after each day.  One site that has completely changed my concept of journalling and the potential of this activity is Kaizen Journalling (kaizenjournaling.com)  which you can refer to for more inspiration and ideas to start your journalling habit!

By necessity, humans had to evolve to become more “self-aware” in order to better support the continuity of the increasingly more complex social system they created. Perhaps during more primordial periods of human existence, self-awareness was not so critical to the survival of a group. During such times, nature and natural instinct were the primary drivers of behavior and group survival, and consciousness or self-awareness served little purpose. Imagine yourself as now back during the primordial period of human existence sitting around the campfire during dinner with a bunch of primitives. Your self-awareness just might turn out to be a big headache for you as you watch and hear your dinner mates rip mostly raw meat from bones with their canines between grunts. No matter how much you’d say to yourself, “Oh… that’s gross! I can’t imagine myself doing that” it’ll probably be best that you kept your complaint to yourself… because they would not care a hoot about that or any other aspect of your self-awareness. Now fast forward: First day on a new job. You’ll need to quickly reflect on who you are as a person so as to meet and relate with they type of workmates you’ll best get along with. You’ll need to re-appraise your skills and abilities to once again consider if they are right for the job. And-oh… when the boss comes around, you’ll need to be especially aware of what you say, how you say it, and how you behave—all for the purpose of continuing to put on a positive impression. As such, your self-awareness serves your ability to succeed on the job, and con- sequently—survive. Additionally, the job you work for, by employing a self-aware, cognizant individual, supports its chances of survival through success. Now do you seriously think that this would also be the case if it were to hire those same “raw- meat-on-the-bone” snacking primitives you sat around the campfire eating dinner with earlier— who might have snacked on you as well had you expressed any self-awareness toward them.

Others Might Know You Better Than You Know Yourself Here’s Why and 4 Practices to Improve Your Self-Awareness How are you perceived by others? How can you become more self-aware? A study conducted at Washington University in St. Louis shows that the people around you sometimes know you better than you know yourself. Here’s an example from my life: I’ve always believed myself to be a compassionate and caring individual. But one day someone pointed out to me that I can be intimidating and intense. I was a bit shocked. I didn’t feel intimidating (in fact, quite the opposite). Trying so hard to focus and help others, I would furrow my brow and look intently at the other person. Someone described it as a “constipated look” on my face. It portrayed an intense and at times intimidating demeanor…I had no idea. I’ve had many more of these blind spots revealed in my life — and I’m sure more are yet to discover. What about you? What gaps do you have between your self-perception and how others perceive you? It’s not easy to know and here’s why.  How Is It That We Are so Self-Unaware? There are several reasons knowing yourself can be challenging. It might be because you lack certain information about yourself. In my case, I never thought to look in a mirror while I was conversing with another person (that would be strange if I did). Or you might possess too much information about yourself. Thoughts, feelings, habits, beliefs, and past experiences are all swirling around in your body and mind. This whirlwind makes it hard to decipher what is true. Most of all, the reason we don’t know ourselves is that we are prone to self-deception. Research shows that people often distort reality to fit their self-image. Our egos seek to protect us, resulting in a natural tendency to justify what we already believe to be true. Why do we have such a divisive culture in the world today? Because our ego spends all its energy conjuring up reasons for why I am right and you are wrong. If you want to improve your conversations and connection with others, then come back and ponder this one later. It’s hard to be self-aware, but a skill you can develop nonetheless. Here are several ideas.   Four Practices to Increase Your Self-Awareness “Man, sometimes it takes a long time to sound like yourself.” — Miles Davis Here are four practices to increase your self-awareness — none of which involve living in a mountainside monastery sipping green tea (I’ve never done anything like that, but it might be helpful too) But let’s start with something practical. 1. Self-Distancing Studies show the best way we can see ourselves clearly and make sound decisions is to create distance from our perceived challenge. Instead of asking yourself, “what should I do?” Ask, “If a friend was experiencing this situation, what advice would I tell them? “ This is an example of self-distancing. Another exercise would be to journal about what’s going on in your life, but as if you were writing about someone else. Writing in the third person is a great way to distance yourself so that you are more objective in deciding how to best move forward. If you want to understand a personal challenge or navigate a difficult situation, then its best to do so without being entangled in all your thoughts and emotions. Self-distancing is a great way to do this. 2. Practice Mindfulness What would it be like if you could observe your thoughts, emotions, and experiences in the moment? What if you could choose what’s helpful and let the rest pass? This is the result of practicing mindfulness for as little as 20 minutes per day. Mindfulness develops your ability to observe and respond to life, rather than swept away by it. Mindfulness allows you to “perceive with clarity the path you are actually on and the direction in which you are going…so that maybe you will be in a better position to chart a course for yourself that is truer to your inner being — a soul path, a path with heart, your path with a capital P,” says Jon Kabat-Zin, leading expert on mindfulness. He defines mindfulness as “the awareness that arises through paying attention on purpose in the present moment — non-judgmentally.” Mindfulness has so much to offer you and is worth exploring deeper.  3. There are two forms of self-awareness. The first is awareness of your internal state. The second is awareness of your external state. Both are crucial for your success and happiness. Internal awareness is when you are able to watch your thoughts and notice your emotions. It involves watching your thoughts as if you are separate from them. This form of awareness is important in learning what drives you and what your purpose is for doing what you do. External awareness involves being able to see yourself through the eyes of someone else. This form of awareness is important for knowing how other people think about you and how they react to you. If you’ve ever been trapped in a conversation where you’re showing all the signs that you want to leave but the other person just keeps talking, you have witnessed a lack of external awareness. So how do you get both forms of awareness? Luckily, you can work on both at the same time. Here are the five methods you can use: 1. Writing. I can’t stress enough how great writing is for your self-awareness. Even if you never want a single word to be seen by the public, start writing your thoughts. Nicolas Cole got me into writing and it’s been a game-changer for understanding myself. Start with a journal or an empty Word document and just starting writing your thoughts. I call this a “Brain Dump.” When I have a difficult decision to make, I’ll open a Word document and start spilling my thoughts on the options. For some reason, every time I do this I leave the session having a much clearer idea of what to do. 2. Walking. My newest self-awareness trick is to take “focus walks.” Throughout the day, I’ll have many things on my mind. However, I never have time to give these thoughts all my attention because something always interrupts my thinking. A focus walk is the cure. Have your topic in mind and go for a 15–30 minute walk, alone and with no phone. Just you, the sidewalk, and your thoughts. Try to only think about your one topic. If you get distracted, bring your attention back to the topic. Do this over and over as you walk. You would be very surprised how much you can learn about yourself on one of these walks. I recently went to answer a question about what I want most out of life. This question was so deep that it made me realize I actually didn’t know what I wanted in life. So I took a walk around the block to ponder it and ended up realizing exactly what I wanted most in life mid-way through the walk! 3. Meditation. I honestly think meditation is one of the reasons I know myself so well. I’ve done over 200 meditation sessions and learned a lot through them. Unlike before, I know notice my emotions and my impulses. For example, when I get angry now, I notice my mind say “You’re getting angry right now, what do you walk to do about this?” instead of being caught in the impulse. I also know catch myself when I start judging someone. Instead of immediately calling someone names in my head, I think “Don’t judge him, he is no different than you.” Try an app like Headspace to start (they have a free ten day trial I believe.) I’ve been using it for over a year. 4. Body language. You never want to be the guy or girl who doesn’t notice when he/she is talking way too much or getting strange looks from others. Start paying more attention to the body language people use when they talk to each other. If someone is talking to you and repeatedly breaking eye contact, they might not be that interested in the conversation. Don’t hold them there, give them an easy way out. Check out the book How To Win Friends and Influence People has some good tips. But you can also just start reading about body language online. 5. Lifting weights. Lifting weights is a fantastic way to learn external awareness. At first, you’ll have trouble getting your body to do what you want it to in the gym. You’ll feel the wrong muscles during exercise or feel nothing at all. But after time, you’ll get better at having your mind tell your body exactly what it wants it to do. This is called mind-muscle connection and will greatly improve your external awareness.   To know yourself is one of the most rewarding things you can do. But, it’s also one of the most difficult. Start spending time practicing each of the things listed here and you’ll learn more about yourself than you have in years.

The main idea is to learn self-observation. It’s not a complex skill. Formal sitting meditation is the most “pure” form of that, and that’s a good place to start. But there are many kinds of meditation, some of which do little or nothing to improve self-awareness. So you shouldn’t assume that just because something says “meditation” on the label that it will help with awareness development. To “observe” anything involves attention without reaction. You want to notice your thoughts and feelings, in particular — although it’s also helpful to notice the here-and-now sensory input, body sensations, and other content of your experience. The thing to watch out for is reactive thinking: when you start to self-observe, the mind’s conditioned tendency to “chase thoughts” becomes very apparent. This is reactive thinking, in which one thought triggers another which triggers another, and before long you’re ruminating — trying to figure things out, fantasizing, etc. That’s not observation, that’s thinking. Observation is like watching something. You don’t get involved with what you’re watching, you don’t try to stop it or keep it going, you don’t try to figure it out or analyze it, etc. You just watch. This takes significant discipline… there’s a distinct urge to do all that other stuff, and that must be restrained. As you build skill at observation, you can then start to see patterns, such as associations between certain kinds of thinking and certain experiences or feelings. This “higher level” kind of observing is where you start to understand the mind — what is it trying to do? What is the underlying driving force of this thinking and feeling? etc. I like certain kinds of questions as “stimulators” of awareness. I call them ‘probe questions’. Once you’re able to stabilize your attention so that you’re not chasing thoughts all the time, it can be useful to add a practice of tossing in these questions occasionally. This is similar to koan practice in Zen (I was a Zen student years ago.) It’s as if you’re sending something down into the unconscious mind — you can’t control where it goes or whether it falls into the void, etc., you just drop it over the side and let go of it. Not in the true sense of that term. Someone could become too caught up in knowing details about various aspects of their body, mind, life, etc. - but that is essentially the opposite of true self-knowledge. Genuine self-knowledge arise from becoming consciously familiar with the full range of consciousness. From the surface-most physical and mental activities, to deeper layers of memory and intuition, and all the way to original, unconditioned awareness - the awareness that’s aware of everything else. Unconditioned awareness is also referred to as the ground (meaning foundation) of being, because there’s nothing deeper than it. Everything in experience, thought, memory, etc. is contained within the field of awareness, in which everything is experienced. Unconditioned awareness is also known as the “natural state” - because it’s the natural human condition, prior to the obscuring that comes from over-focus on thoughts, feelings and outer circumstances. It’s called the natural state, because it’s always already here. Any experience would be impossible without it. But everyone in the modern world has been conditioned to be aware of all the objects in awareness, including the most subtle thoughts and feelings - but not on the awareness itself, that makes any experience even possible. And so, self-knowledge doesn’t need to be gained. Everything that’s in the way of it it just needs to be removed, by not longer fueling conceptual obstructions with attention and emotion. That’s why processes and practices such as meditation, self-inquiry (noticing what is not actually you; uncovering what is prior to all thoughts, emotions, etc.), presence (simply being aware, in the present moment, of direct sensory input) are powerful tools: they all help to become consciously aware of original, unconditioned awareness - which is the self-realization that is beyond self-knowledge. In certain ancient writings, knowledge is referred to as bondage. That’s because specific knowledge is an object in awareness, which creates the sense of being a subject - the “I” that has the specific knowledge - all of which takes place within the original, unconditioned awareness that is actual self-knowledge, when directly, consciously experienced. And the only thing needed to do that is to withdraw attention from everything - just let attention rest. What remains is unconditioned awareness, aka self-knowledge.

Source: The miracle of Mindfulness  by thich nhat hanh.Every day and every hour, one should practice mindfulness. That's easy to say, but to carry it out in practice is Not.in principle, of course every day should be your day, and every hour your hour. But the fact is that very few of us have reached such a point. We have the impression that our family, place of work, and society rob us of all our time. So I urge that everyone set aside one day each week. Saturday, perhaps.If it is Saturday, then Saturday must be entirely your day, a day during which you are completely the master. Then Saturday will be the lever that will lift you to the habit of practicing mindfulness. Every worker in a peace or service community, no matter how urgent its work, has the right to such a day, for without it we will lose ourselves quickly in a life full of worry and action, and our responses will become increasingly useless. Whatever the day chosen, it can be considered as the day of mindfulness.To set up a day of mindfulness, figure out a way to remind yourself at the moment of waking that this day is your day of mindfulness. You might hang something on the ceiling or on the wall, a paper with the word "mindfulness" or a pine branch - anything that will suggest to you as you open your eyes and see it that today is your day of mindfulness. Today is your day. Remembering that, perhaps you can feel a smile which affirms that you are in complete mindfulness, a smile that nourishes that perfect mindfulness.While still lying in bed, begin slowly to follow your breath - slow, long, and conscious breaths. Then slowly rise from bed (instead of turning out all at once as usual), nourishing mindfulness by every motion. Once up, brush your teeth, wash your face, and do all your morning activities in a calm and relaxing way, each movement done in mindfulness. Follow your breath, take hold of it, and don't let your thoughts scatter. Each movement should be done calmly. Measure your steps with quiet, long breaths. Maintain a half smile.At lunchtime, prepare a meal for yourself. Cook the meal and wash the dishes in mindfulness. In the morning, after you have cleaned and straightened up your house, and in the afternoon, after you have worked in the garden or watched clouds or gathered flowers, prepare a pot of tea to sit and drink in mindfulness. Allow yourself a good length of time to do this. Don't drink your tea like someone who gulps down a cup of coffee during a work break. Drink your tea slowly and reverently, as if it is the axis on which the whole earth revolves - slowly, evenly, without rushing toward the future. Live the actual moment. Only this actual moment is life. Don't be attached to the future. Don't worry about things you have to do. Don't think about getting up or taking off to do anything. Don't think about "departing." In the evening, you might read scripture and copy passages, write letters to friends, or do anything else you enjoy outside of your normal duties during the week. But whatever you do, do it in mindfulness. Eat only a little for the evening meal. Later, around 10 or 11 o'clock, as you sit in meditation, you will be able to sit more easily on an empty stomach. Afterwards you might take a slow walk in the fresh night air, following your breath in mindfulness and measuring the length of your breaths by your steps. Finally, return to your room and sleep in mindfulness.

One day after class, he suggested that it might be helpful for me to take an intentional break at moments during class, shutting my eyes and taking a couple of deep breaths, and then scanning my body from my head down to my toes, noticing any tension and relaxing each area as I moved down. If needed, I could do this a couple of times and I could do it as often as I needed to to become more relaxed and focused. He said I would have his blessings to do this, so that I shouldn’t worry about what he or anyone else in the class thought about it; I should just feel free to do it. I practiced this regularly from that point on, and much later in life I realized how beneficial this had been for me. In short, no. What does it actually mean to be completely self-aware? It's an ultimate extent or absolute, and reality doesn't function on absolutes. What would you be aware of when you are completely self-aware? Aware of all that constitutes your character and personality? Aware of the mechanism by which your brain functions? Aware of all that constitutes you? Aware of all that constitutes you and how you relate to reality? If we were to come even close to any of these, that would be rather profound already. I would say to be completely self-aware means there is no way to function at all; we function exactly because we are not aware of everything — interior or otherwise. Our experience of reality is an inherent reduction (this is called the Phaneron), and so is self-awareness. This couldn't be overcome by any organism. And what does it mean to be 100% aware? To be 100% aware would mean locally you pick up all of reality that could be perceived or experienced, and no longer an inherent reduction. This would take an insane amount of computing power, way beyond the capacity of our brain. To be 100% self-aware wouldn't be quite as demanding, yet I postulate it's still a physical impossibility. To be completely self-aware you likely need more computing power than the brain can offer; the sufficient amount of computing power to know itself would likely expand the required computing power to know itself beyond the initial requirement, and so you could never actually reach such a level of self-awareness unless you outsource some of that computing power. I suspect the only way in which one could even attempt to become completely self-aware in theory would be to expand the body by artificial means, extending the functionality of the brain and outsourcing computing power. The problem however is that if you extend the computing power, you extend the system itself and so there would be more to be self-aware about. Unless you don't count the extended system as part of what should become self-aware, this leads to an inherent infinite regress.

Personally I think the best way to become self-aware is to realize how much power interpretation has on our conception of reality. Try to read multiple perspectives on news items, subjects of contention in the media and among your friends, and really try and set aside your personal feelings in order to understand what might cause a person to see each of these perspectives as true. When you realize that every person's perceptions are colored by their prior experiences and see how personal narratives can cause the same situation to be read differently by different people, you'll likely start to apply that same multiple-lens approach to your judgments about yourself, too. In my opinion, that's what being self-aware is—seeing how other people see what you do, how you look, and how you speak and being able to shift your point of view to stand in front of each of those mirrors at different moments. People who are self-absorbed are incapable of seeing anything but their own interpretation of themselves, what they meant by the action instead of what the impact of that action was on others, how they think they look versus how someone else (and potentially everyone else) sees them. And that's how you end up thinking your mullet is cool.

The more we understand the relationship between our choices and our emotions, the more we realise how little we understand about the relationship between our choices and emotions. The only people who won’t benefit from ‘more’ self-awareness, as those who are perfect. Will all the perfect people PLEASE stand up and share your memoirs about how you’ve done it! There is no how. Because, in the mirror of awareness, both self and world (or, others), are reflected. It’s just that you attend to only what the world is and completely ignore what self is. Self-awareness is not continuous; there are intervals of it. Continuity is not even required. There are periods of silence; there are gaps between stimuli (causes) and responses (effects). In those gaps & intervals, you become aware of what you have been (in relation to the world). There’s nothing you can do about what you are when you become aware of yourself (or, your self). But, because by your persistent ignorance of self-awareness, you have completely lost to yourself. To regain, just attend to the moments of silence, gaps, intervals; pay intense attention just as you do to your worldly affairs like movies, holidays, etc. As the intensity of this attention grows, world will not fall from you but you will regain your true self, which is now lost to you.
